title-group.article-title: Childhood adversity, current adversity and cognitive frailty among older adults in rural China: does social support play a role?

trans-title-group.trans-title: Adversidad en la infancia, adversidad actual y fragilidad cognitiva en adultos mayores de zonas rurales en China: ¿cumple un rol el apoyo social?

abstract.title: ABSTRACT
abstract.p: Background: Little is known regarding the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty, and the role of social support in this relationship.

Objective: This study aimed to investigate the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty, as well as determine how social support affects this relationship among rural older adults in China.

Methods: Data were obtained from two waves of follow-up surveys (2020 and 2022) conducted by the Shandong Rural Elderly Health Cohort (SREHC), including 2,572 participants aged 60 years or above. The primary outcome was cognitive frailty, defined as the co-existence of physical frailty (≥3 Fried criteria) and cognitive impairment (educationally adjusted Mini-Mental Status Examination). Self-reported adverse experiences were categorised as no adversity, only childhood adversity (≥1 of 12 events before age 17), only current adversity (≥1 of 7 events past year), and dual adversity (experiencing both childhood and current adversity). The Generalized Estimating Equation (GEE) analyses and the margins plot were performed to estimate our hypothetical models.

Results: In fully adjusted models, older adults with dual adversity were significantly associated with a higher risk of cognitive frailty (OR = 1.64, 95% CI: 1.02–2.63), not significant in only childhood or only current adversity. Social support alleviated the risk of cognitive frailty among rural older adults with only childhood adversity (OR = 0.41, 95% CI: 0.21–0.79) or dual adversity (OR = 0.26, 95% CI: 0.09–0.72), but not among those with only current adversity.

Conclusions: Our results underscore the relationship between dual adversity and cognitive frailty, not significant in only childhood or only current adversity, with social support serving as a pivotal moderating factor. Governmental authorities should elevate their awareness of adverse experiences, and enhancing social support is crucial to preventing cognitive frailty and promoting healthy aging.

list-item.p: Dual adversity was associated with cognitive frailty.
No significant association between only current or childhood adversity and cognitive frailty.
Social support buffered cognitive frailty for older adults with only childhood or dual adversity, but not among those with only current adversity.

trans-abstract.p: Antecedentes: Poco se sabe sobre la asociación entre las experiencias adversas y la fragilidad cognitiva, así como el rol del apoyo social en esta relación.

Objetivo: Este estudio tuvo como objetivo investigar la asociación entre las experiencias adversas y la fragilidad cognitiva, además de determinar cómo influye el apoyo social en dicha relación en adultos mayores que viven en zonas rurales de China.

Métodos: Los datos se obtuvieron de dos olas de encuestas de seguimiento (2020 y 2022) realizadas por la Cohorte de Salud de Adultos Mayores Rurales de Shandong (SREHC), e incluyeron a 2.572 participantes de 60 años o más. El resultado principal fue la fragilidad cognitiva, definida como la coexistencia de fragilidad física (≥3 criterios de Fried) y deterioro cognitivo (evaluado mediante el Mini-Mental Status Examination ajustado por nivel educativo). Las experiencias adversas auto reportadas se clasificaron en: sin adversidad, solo adversidad en la infancia (≥1 de 12 eventos antes de los 17 años), solo adversidad actual (≥1 de 7 eventos en el último año) y adversidad dual (ambas). Se utilizaron análisis mediante ecuaciones de estimación generalizadas (GEE) y gráficos de márgenes para estimar los modelos hipotéticos.

Resultados: En los modelos completamente ajustados, los adultos mayores que experimentaron adversidad dual presentaron un riesgo significativamente mayor de fragilidad cognitiva (OR = 1,64; IC 95%: 1,02–2,63), asociación no significativa en quienes vivieron solo adversidad en la infancia o solo adversidad actual. El apoyo social redujo el riesgo de fragilidad cognitiva en quienes presentaban solo adversidad en la infancia (OR = 0,41; IC 95%: 0,21–0,79) o adversidad dual (OR = 0,26; IC 95%: 0,09–0,72), pero no en aquellos con solo adversidad actual.

Conclusiones: Nuestros resultados destacan la asociación entre la adversidad dual y la fragilidad cognitiva, no observada de forma significativa cuando la adversidad es solo en la infancia o solo actual. El apoyo social emerge como un factor moderador clave. Es fundamental que las autoridades gubernamentales reconozcan el impacto de las experiencias adversas y fortalezcan el apoyo social como medida preventiva frente a la fragilidad cognitiva y para promover un envejecimiento saludable.

institution-wrap.institution: National Natural Science Foundation of China

The study sponsor has no role in study design, data analysis and interpretation of data, the writing of manuscript, or the decision to submit the paper for publication.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the rapid development of the aging population, health issues related to aging are becoming increasingly apparent. Upon entering old age, individuals experience a decline in the functioning of multiple systems, especially the rapid deterioration of physical and cognitive functions (Shimada et al., 2013). Given the inextricable relationship between physical frailty and cognitive impairment, cognitive frailty was first defined in 2013 as ‘a clinical condition in which physical frailty and cognitive impairment coexist, excluding Alzheimer's disease and other dementia’ (Kelaiditi et al., 2013). Cognitive frailty has received widespread attention as an important target for healthy aging research and policy intervention practice. A growing body of research reveals that cognitive frailty is associated with adverse health-related outcomes (Feng et al., 2017), placing a significant burden on individuals, families, and socio-medical systems. Cognitive frailty plays a greater role in predicting disability, dementia, and even all-cause mortality among older adults than only physical frailty or cognitive impairment (Feng et al., 2017; Zheng et al., 2020). Notably, cognitive frailty is reversible, and the implementation of effective early interventions can help to recover or slow its progress (Ruan et al., 2015). Besides, health problems faced by rural older adults, such as cognitive frailty, are particularly acute due to the relative lack of rural healthcare resources in rural areas (Wang et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2022). Thus, identifying risk factors for cognitive frailty among rural older adults is critical to achieving healthy aging.

Adverse experiences, including childhood adversity, current adversity, and dual adversity (experiencing both childhood and current adversity), are widespread among older adults globally (Kessler et al., 2010; Ormel et al., 2001). According to the Risk Accumulation Model (RAM), although some adverse experiences may occur independently, accumulating multiple adverse experiences has a greater impact on health (Ben-Shlomo & Kuh, 2002). Specifically, both childhood adversity and current adversity can bring harm to health, and older adults with childhood adversity may face more serious health problems due to the triggering effects of current adversity (Comijs et al., 2011; Korkeila et al., 2005). Moreover, previous research has shown that individuals with childhood adversity are more likely to experience chronic stress in adulthood and have difficulty responding effectively to stressors in later life (Künzi et al., 2023; Richardson et al., 2023; Wang, 2023). Thus, integrating childhood adversity and current adversity reveals the compounding effects of adverse experiences on health in old age, thereby contributing to well-being in later life.

As a multifaceted stressor, adverse experiences (childhood adversity or current adversity) have been proven to be associated with a range of negative health outcomes in later life (Comijs et al., 2011; Richardson et al., 2023; Trinidad, 2021). An increasing number of empirical studies have shown that older adults who have experienced childhood adversity or current adversity are more likely to have cognitive impairment, such as deficits in executive function, memory, and more (Ding & He, 2021; Shi et al., 2025; Trinidad, 2021; Wang et al., 2024; Zhang et al., 2022). Other studies have identified associations between adverse experiences (childhood adversity or current adversity) and worse physical frailty among older adults (Freitag & Schmidt, 2016; Makino et al., 2024; Papathanasiou et al., 2021; Trinidad, 2021; Wang, 2023). Existing studies have focused on the relationship between adverse experiences (childhood adversity or current adversity) and the components of cognitive frailty (cognitive impairment and physical frailty), respectively. However, no study has investigated the association between childhood adversity and current adversity in terms of their combined occurrence and cognitive frailty.

Of note, social support, as a health-beneficial social factor, is critical to improving the health and well-being of older adults (Fahmy, 2021). Social support refers to ‘the actual help and support received and perceived by individuals through social contacts and participation’ (Kelly et al., 2017). The stress-buffering effect model indicates that social support can be a key external resource for individuals to cope with stress during stressful situations, maximising the buffering of the negative effects of stressors on health (Cohen, 2004; Cohen & Wills, 1985). Growing evidence suggests that social support is strongly associated with cognitive frailty among older adults (Wang et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2022), as well as acts as a buffer between spousal loss and cognitive frailty (Lim-Soh & Carr, 2022; Wang et al., 2024; Zhang et al., 2022). Spousal loss (being widowed or divorced) is recognised as one of the most stressful adverse experiences facing older adults (d'Epinay et al., 2009). Given this, good social support is effective in reducing stress responses and improving behavioural adaptation in older adults who have experienced adversity, thereby slowing the process of cognitive frailty. Correspondingly, older adults with low social support may lack stress-coping resources, creating secondary stressors that further exacerbate cognitive frailty. However, few studies have examined whether social support moderates the adverse experiences-cognitive frailty relationship.

Based on the abovementioned background, this study aimed to explore the relationship between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty, as well as how social support influences this relationship among rural older adults. We proposed the following specific hypotheses: (1) dual adversity increased the risk of cognitive frailty among rural older adults; (2) the buffering effect of social support on the above relationship. This study will provide new empirical evidence for optimising cognitive frailty prevention strategies and improving the health and well-being of rural older adults.

sec.title: Data source and participants
sec.p: This study constitutes a secondary analysis of data from the Shandong Rural Elderly Health Cohort (SREHC). While the original SREHC was designed to investigate general behaviour and health status in rural older adults (Wang et al., 2021), the present study tested new hypotheses about childhood/current adversity, social support, and cognitive frailty – objectives that were not predefined in the main cohort protocol. All variables analyzed herein (cognitive frailty, social support, adversity exposures) were systematically collected from two follow-up surveys of the SREHC in 2020 and 2022 using validated instruments, ensuring methodological alignment despite distinct research aims. SREHC, with a baseline survey conducted in 2019, selected study participants using a multi-stage stratified cluster sampling method. First, all counties in Shandong Province were classified as high, medium, and low based on their per capita GDP in 2018 by using quantile classification method, sourced from the Shandong Statistical Yearbook 2019. From each group, one sample county was randomly selected respectively, including Rushan in Weihai (high level), Qufu in Jining (medium level), and Laoling in Dezhou (low level). Then, 5 townships were randomly selected from each sampled county. From each township, 4 communities/villages were selected, and 60 older adults aged 60 and above were randomly selected from these communities/villages to complete the questionnaire survey. Three rural counties, 15 townships, 60 villages, and 3,600 older adults were recruited.

Data were collected face-to-face by well-trained investigators with adequate knowledge, using structured questionnaires (Wang et al., 2021). To ensure data quality and completeness, quality supervisors reviewed each completed questionnaire at the end of the day. As shown in Figure S1, 2,900 older adults completed two rounds of follow-up surveys (2020 and 2022). Participants with missing primary variables (cognitive frailty and social support) were excluded (n = 328). Finally, this study included 2,572 participants.

sec.title: Cognitive frailty
sec.p: This study used the frailty phenotype and the Mini-Mental Status Examination (MMSE) to measure cognitive frailty jointly (Folstein et al., 1975; Fried et al., 2001). Physical frailty was calculated based on frailty phenotype criteria proposed by Fried et al (Fried et al., 2001). Frailty phenotype was composed of 5 physiological indicators: unintentional weight loss, self-reported exhaustion, reduced grip strength, low physical activity, and slow gait speed, with scores ranging from 0 to 5. In this study, physical frailty was categorised as frailty and without frailty. Of these, participants with 3–5 criteria were considered frail. Cognitive impairment was assessed by the MMSE, which has excellent reliability and validity (Wang et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2022; Zhao et al., 2021). The MMSE consisted of 30 items (ranging from 0 to 30), with higher scores indicating better cognitive function. Concerning the level of education, the cut-off values for cognitive impairment of the MMSE were ≤ 17 (for illiterate participants), ≤ 20 (for primary school participants), ≤ 22 (for junior school participants), and ≤ 24 (for university or above participants), respectively (Katayama et al., 2021; Ma et al., 2019; Zhang et al., 2022; Zhao et al., 2021). The tested in this study and the results showed good reliability and validity (McDonald's Omega coefficients of 0.796 and 0.880, respectively, and KMO values of 0.761 and 0.887, respectively). Ultimately, cognitive frailty was determined by the co-existence of physical frailty and cognitive impairment.

sec.title: Adverse experiences
sec.p: Adverse experiences included older adults’ adverse childhood experiences and current adversity. Specifically, adverse childhood experiences were constructed by interviewing older adults about adverse events experienced during childhood (before age 17), including 12 events: physical abuse, emotional neglect, parental substance abuse, parental mental illness, domestic violence, parental separation or divorce, parents incarcerated, parental death, death of siblings, serious illness of a close relative, and other adversity (being safe out alone at night and peer bullying). These events were selected based on theoretical foundations and relevant literature, including the trauma exposure model for health risk prediction (Lloyd & Turner, 2003; Turner et al., 2016), the WHO World Mental Health Survey's classification of childhood adversity (Kessler et al., 2010), and adaptations for older adults in China (Ding & He, 2021). The variable was dichotomous, the participants who experienced any of the above events were coded 1, indicating the presence of childhood adversity. Otherwise, it was coded as 0, indicating without childhood adversity. This approach aligns with cumulative adversity research and has demonstrated significant predictive validity for health outcomes in prior studies (Ding & He, 2021; Zhou et al., 2025).

Current adversity was constructed by structuring interviews with older adults about events experienced in the past 12 months. Based on theoretical foundations and relevant literature (Bjorndal, 2023; Pries et al., 2020; Zhou et al., 2025), we included 7 negative life events that significantly impact the lives of older adults: serious illness, natural disaster, death of a spouse or child, property loss, serious illness of family members, and accident. Each event was encoded as a binary variable (0 = not experienced, 1 = experienced), with participants reporting ≥1 event classified into the adversity group. This measurement approach is consistent with established methodologies in life event research and has shown predictive validity for health outcomes (such as depression and cognition) among older adults (Bjorndal, 2023; Pries et al., 2020; Zhou et al., 2025). Finally, based on the assessment results for childhood and current adversities, subjects were categorised into four groups: no adversity, only current adversity, only childhood adversity, and dual adversity.

sec.title: Social support
sec.p: The Social Support Rating Scale (SSRS) was employed to assess the social support of participants (Xiao, 1994). This scale has been validated as a high reliability and validity measure in China (Lin et al., 2020). The SSRS consists of 10 items, covering three dimensions: subjective support (4 items), objective support (3 items), and support utilisation (3 items). The total SSRS score ranges from 12 to 66, with higher scores indicating that the individual receives more social support. Based on the median social support level, participants in this study were categorised into two groups: a high social support group and a low social support group. In this study, the scale was tested to have good reliability and validity (McDonald's Omega = 0.732, KMO value = 0.801).

sec.title: Covariates
sec.p: Based on previous research (Li et al., 2025; Maroto-Rodriguez et al., 2024; Wang et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2022), multiple potential covariates associated with cognitive frailty were included and divided into three categories: socio-demographic, lifestyle, and health-related variables. Socio-demographic characteristics included age, gender (male or female), highest education level (illiteracy, primary school, or middle school or above), marital status (unmarried/divorced/widowed or married), and household income (Quartile 1 to Quartile 4, from poorest to richest). Lifestyle variables included smoking (yes or no), drinking (yes or no), plant-based diet index (PDI) score, and leisure activities. The PDI included 3 types of food and 14 dietary groups: healthy plant foods (6 items), less healthy plant foods (3 items), and animal foods (5 items) (Tang et al., 2023). Each item had 5 frequency response categories, ranging from ‘rarely or never’ to ‘almost every day’ on a scale of 1–5. The total PDI score was calculated by summing the scores from each of the constituent food groups, which theoretically ranged from 14 to 70. Leisure activities were assessed by asking older adults whether they participated in 8 activities every week (watching TV, surfing the Internet, playing cards/mahjong/chess, etc.), with 5 frequency answer categories ranging from ‘never or less’ to ‘almost every day’. The overall score ranged from 8 to 40, with higher scores indicating more intense leisure activities. Health-related variables included activities of daily living (ADL) limitations and chronic conditions [no chronic condition, one chronic condition, multimorbidity (the coexistence of two or more chronic conditions)]. The Katz index scale was employed to assess ADL limitations, which included 14 items with scores ranging from 14 to 56 points. A score of ≥15 indicated ADL limitations based on proposed cut-off scores (Katz et al., 1963). In this study, the scale was tested to have good reliability and validity (McDonald's Omega = 0.885, KMO value = 0.935). According to the Chinese Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommendations, 12 categories of chronic diseases (hypertension, dyslipidemia, stroke, etc.) were included in SREHC.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: All analyses were performed using Stata 18.0 (Stata Corp, College Station, TX, USA). First, the characteristics of participants were compared by cognitive frailty using chi-square tests (for categorical variables) and student t-tests (for continuous variables). Second, the generalised estimating equation (GEE) models were used to evaluate the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty (Ballinger, 2004). To account for multiple comparisons arising from the four-category exposure variable, we applied Benjamini-Hochberg false discovery rate (FDR) correction to the three pairwise comparisons against the reference group (No adversity). Model 1 adjusted for age, gender, education, marital status, household income, and year; Model 2 adjusted for smoking, drinking, PDI score, and leisure activities based on Model 1; Model 3 adjusted for social support, ADL limitations, and chronic conditions based on Model 2. Third, based on the full model, the moderating effect of adverse experiences and social support on cognitive frailty was further explored by incorporating the interaction term (adverse experiences × social support). Simultaneously, a margin plot was employed to illustrate the predicted cognitive frailty based on adverse experiences and social support.

To further examine the robustness of the associations between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty, we conducted several sensitivity analyses: (1) excluding participants with cognitive frailty at baseline, and using Cox proportional risk regression models to estimate the associations between adverse experiences, current adverse experiences counts, and adverse childhood experiences counts and the incidence of cognitive frailty during follow-up, respectively; (2) applying generalised linear mixed models to test the research hypotheses (GLMM); (3) Testing moderation using centred continuous social support scores; (4) applying multiple imputation via chained equations to impute missing values in covariates. Missing data were assumed to be random and interpolation was performed 20 times. All reported p-values from primary analyses were uncorrected; FDR-corrected q-values were provided in supplementary materials. Statistical significance was set at α = 0.05 (two-sided).

sec.title: Ethical consideration
sec.p: The SREHC, including baseline (2019) and follow-up surveys (2020, 2022), was reviewed and approved by the Ethics Committee of Shandong University (approval number, 20181228; approval date: 28 December 2018). All participants provided written informed consent at enrolment, authorising data use for longitudinal research.

sec.title: Basic characteristics of participants
sec.p:
Table 1 presents the characteristics of respondents by cognitive frailty at baseline. The average age of the 2572 participants was 70.85 years (SD = 5.83), 1580 (61.43%) were female, 1040 (40.44%) were illiterate, 2013 (78.33%) were married, and 634 (24.66%) had a lower household income. Among all respondents, the prevalence of cognitive frailty was 5.60%. Older adults with cognitive frailty were more likely to be older (p < .001), female (p = .002), illiterate (p < .001), married (p < .001), poorly household income (p < .001), have a lower lever of social support (p < .001) and leisure activities (p < .001), have ADL limitations (p < .001), and multimorbidity (p = .001) than those without cognitive frailty. Also, 1977 (76.87%) participants had adverse experiences. Table 1.

sec.title: Association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty
sec.p:
Table 2 shows GEE results on the relationship between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty among rural older adults. Multiple models of GEE revealed that adverse experiences were significantly associated with a higher risk of cognitive frailty. Older adults with dual adversity were 1.75, 1.82, and 1.64 times more likely to have cognitive frailty than those without adverse experiences, respectively (Model 1: 95% CI = 1.10–2.79, p = .019; Model 2: 95% CI = 1.14–2.92, p = .012; Model 3: 95% CI = 1.02–2.63, p = .039). No significant associations between only current adversity (Model 1: OR = 0.62, 95% CI = 0.24–1.65; Model 2: OR = 0.65, 95% CI = 0.25–1.70; Model 3: OR = 0.61, 95% CI = 0.24–1.55), or only childhood adversity (Model 1: OR = 1.09, 95% CI = 0.77–1.55; Model 2: OR = 1.08, 95% CI = 0.77–1.53; Model 3: OR = 0.99, 95% CI = 0.71–1.40) and cognitive frailty were found among rural older adults. Benjamini-Hochberg FDR-corrected q-values for pairwise comparisons are provided in Table S1. Also, Figure 1 shows a forest plot of dual adverse experiences increasing the risk of having cognitive frailty among rural older adults. Figure 1.
The forest plot of the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty among older adults in rural areas.Forest plot showing the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty among rural older adults. Older adults with dual adversity had significantly higher risk of cognitive frailty (OR=1.64, 95% CI:1.02-2.63) compared to no-adversity reference. Table 2.

Notes: Statistically significant p < .05 values are indicated in bold.a

sec.title: Moderating role of social support
sec.p:
We incorporated an interaction term of adverse experiences and social support to further explore whether the relationship between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty varied by social support in Table 3. The significant interaction terms (Only childhood adversity × high social support: OR = 0.41, 95%CI: 0.21–0.79, p = .007; dual adversity × high social support: OR = 0.26, 95%CI: 0.09–0.72, p = .010) indicated that high social support alleviated the risk of cognitive frailty among rural older adults with only childhood or dual adversity, but not in those with only current adversity. Furthermore, Figure 2 illustrates social support moderated the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty. Figure 2.
Interaction between adverse experiences and social support in the prediction of cognitive frailty.Marginal effects plot with 95% CIs illustrating how high social support alleviated the negative impact of only childhood and dual adversity on cognitive frailty probability among rural older adults. Table 3.

sec.title: Sensitivity analyses
sec.p: Multiple sensitivity analyses further validated the robustness of the main findings: (1) Cox regression models excluding participants with cognitive frailty at baseline presented similar patterns of the associations. Also, the results of the transformational analyses of the exposure variables (current and childhood adversity counts) were consistent with the primary analysis (Supplementary Table S2); (2) The GLMM results were highly consistent with the GEE models (Supplementary Table S3); (3) Moderated effects analyses tested using centred continuous social support scores showed similar strength of association (Supplementary Table S4); (4) Imputing missing values in covariates, effect estimates were generally consistent with the main analyses (Supplementary Table S5).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This longitudinal study is the first to investigate the association between adverse experiences and cognitive frailty, and how social support affects this relationship among rural older adults. Our findings revealed that older adults with dual adversity were independently associated with higher risks of cognitive frailty, not significant in only childhood or only current adversity, while also highlighting the moderating role of social support. Specifically, the buffer effect of social support on cognitive frailty was observed in older adults with only childhood or dual adversity, but not in those with only current adversity. Thus, it is necessary to pay more attention to older adults who have experienced adversity, enhancing their social support, thereby reducing the risk of cognitive frailty.

This study revealed that older adults with dual adversity were more likely to have cognitive frailty than those without adverse experiences. Although there is no direct research on the association between dual adversity and cognitive frailty, some studies have found that adverse experiences (childhood adversity or current adversity) are associated with cognitive impairment and physical frailty among older adults, respectively, which provides support for the dual adversity-cognitive frailty relationship (Freitag & Schmidt, 2016; Papathanasiou et al., 2021; Shi et al., 2025; Wang, 2023; Wang et al., 2024). In brief, this process is driven by the interplay of neurophysiological and psychological mechanisms of chronic stress and reduced coping capacity, increasing susceptibility to cognitive frailty in later life (Burnes & Burnette, 2013). First, the direct link between dual adversity and cognitive frailty can be explained by neurobiological mechanisms. On the one hand, adverse experiences chronically stimulate stress systems (e.g. the HPA axis) (Huang et al., 2023), triggering abnormalities in hippocampal (related to memory and learning) function (Burnes & Burnette, 2013). These physiological changes accelerate neurodegeneration, increasing the risk of cognitive frailty (Lupien et al., 2007). On the other hand, adverse experiences are associated with inflammatory responses (Lin et al., 2021). Older adults with adversity have significantly higher inflammatory cytokines (e.g. white blood cell counts, C-reactive protein, and hemoglobin concentrations) (Danese et al., 2007). Significantly, neuroinflammation, particularly the inflammatory response caused by pro-inflammatory cytokines, is a common pathological mechanism for cognitive frailty (Perry et al., 2007). Second, from a psychosocial perspective, adverse experiences, especially childhood adversity, usually lead individuals to develop poor emotion regulation and coping strategies (Burnes & Burnette, 2013; Künzi et al., 2023). Older adults with childhood adversity may bear a greater psychological burden when faced with current adversity, causing mood disorders such as depression, anxiety, and loneliness (Korkeila et al., 2005). Chronic unregulated emotional stress increases physical frailty and cognitive decline among older adults, increasing the risk of cognitive frailty (Comijs et al., 2011; Ding & He, 2021; Papathanasiou et al., 2021; Wang, 2023). However, no significant association was found between only current adversity or only childhood adversity and cognitive frailty. This may be related to adaptive compensatory mechanisms for adversity (Künzi et al., 2023). Individuals develop certain adaptive mechanisms to cope with adversity at different times, compensating to some extent for the negative effects of adversity. A single adversity, such as only childhood or current adversity, may not be sufficient to affect cognitive frailty significantly. Conversely, dual adversity (experiencing both childhood and current adversity) may have a more severe cumulative effect (Korkeila et al., 2005; Wang, 2023), exacerbating the deterioration of brain structure and function, thereby increasing the risk of cognitive frailty.

To be emphasised, social support alleviated the effects of dual adversity on cognitive frailty among rural older adults. In other words, the long-term psychological burdens and life challenges associated with dual adversity can exacerbate the process of cognitive frailty, while social support can alleviate it. Previous literature suggests that social support plays a key role in the chain of relationships between adverse experiences and health status (cognitive impairment and physical frailty) (Wang et al., 2024; Zhang et al., 2022). This finding was consistent with the Conservation of Resources (COR) theory, which suggests that social resources can protect against the negative health effects of adverse experiences (Burnes & Burnette, 2013; Hobfoll & Lilly, 1993). This theory has been further extended to the field of cognitive frailty, suggesting that external support resources can facilitate effective responses to traumatic events by reducing the perceived severity of threats and enhancing the ability to cope with stress (Guay et al., 2006). Specifically, social support, as an externally available resource, can effectively alleviate the stress response associated with these adversities and promote psychological recovery via emotional support and practical help, thereby reducing the negative effects of dual adversity on cognitive frailty (Burnes & Burnette, 2013). Also, social support is regarded as a source of ‘mental stimulation’ for older adults with dual adversity, which can help to slow down the process of cognitive frailty (Schwartz et al., 2019).

Interestingly, the buffer effect of social support on cognitive frailty was observed in older adults with only childhood or dual adversity, but not in those with only current adversity. As cumulative inequality theory suggests, childhood is a critical period contributing to social inequality (Dannefer, 2003). Childhood traumatic stressors have long-term effects on individual development, resources, and social function (Ferraro et al., 2016), which exacerbate cognitive frailty in later life (Ding & He, 2021; Trinidad, 2021), mainly by limiting or altering an individual's social support network and the ability to cope with future stressors (Umberson et al., 2014). Hence, the compensatory role of social support in later life is particularly important, to alleviate the negative emotions and stress associated with childhood adversity, enhance psychological resilience, and reduce the effects of long-term stress on cognitive frailty. In contrast, current adversity (bereavement, serious illness, etc.) is usually acute and situational, with a more transient stress response (Künzi et al., 2023), which has a more direct and immediate impact on cognitive frailty. Despite the positive role of social support in coping with stress (Cohen, 2004; Cohen & Wills, 1985), the sources of stress from current adversity are more specific and urgent, and often beyond the capacity of social support to moderate. For example, major events such as the death of a spouse or child can be deeply emotionally traumatic. While social support can provide some solace, individuals often feel isolated or that their support networks are unable to cope effectively when faced with these major changes. Consequently, the moderating effect of social support in such contexts is less pronounced than in only childhood adversity or dual adversity, and may even become ‘ineffective’.

A key counter-intuitive finding is that older adults with cognitive frailty were more likely to be married. This challenges the traditional notion that marriage protects health. Emerging evidence suggested that the protective effect of marriage on cognition is inherently dependent on relationship quality rather than legal status (Karakose et al., 2025; Robles et al., 2014). Low-quality marriages may exert neurotoxic stress, increase levels of inflammatory factors, and directly accelerate hippocampal atrophy, potentially acting as a risk factor for cognitive frailty (Karakose et al., 2025; Lawrence et al., 2019). In rural China, the decoupling of marital status from quality is common. Older women, who make up a larger proportion of the cognitive frailty group, are more likely to be economically dependent in their marriages (exchanging household labour for means of survival) and lack emotional support and autonomy (Liu & Waite, 2014; Williams & Umberson, 2004). Such marriages, while maintaining their legal form, transform into chronic stressors to increase the risk of cognitive frailty. Future research must incorporate indicators of marital quality to dissect this complex association.

Despite the limitations of observational design, these findings provided preliminary insights with potential implications for policy and practice. First, developing specific strategies targeted at preventing cognitive frailty for high-risk subgroups (e.g. rural older adults with dual adversity) through community-based risk screening programmes. Secondly, exploring contextualised support models, especially in rural areas. Advocating the establishment of volunteer activities and mutual-help networks within communities to enhance emotional support for older adults with adversity, thereby reducing their risk of cognitive frailty. Besides, considering the different roles of social support on cognitive frailty among older adults with different types of adversity, it is recommended that differentiated interventions be designed according to the specific experiences of older adults (e.g. childhood adversity or dual adversity). Future longitudinal and intervention studies are needed to validate these approaches before broader policy implementation is carried out.

Several limitations must be considered when interpreting our findings. First, retrospective assessment of childhood adversity and current adversity may lead to recall bias. And, it is difficult to determine whether the underreporting of events is due to memory problems or the overreporting of events is due to negative emotions. Second, due to data limitations, the severity and duration of each adversity were not assessed in the present study, which could be further explored in the future. Third, the measure of childhood adversity lacked systematic coding of participant-specified adversity, which may underestimate adverse events in specific cultural contexts. Future research should incorporate standardised open-ended responses. Fourth, it is unclear whether the adverse experiences involved in this study have similar effects on cognitive frailty in other countries with different values and socio-cultural characteristics. The generalizability of our findings requires further validation.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study confirmed for the first time that dual adversity was associated with an increased risk of cognitive frailty among rural older adults, with the buffer effect of social support on this association. However, the buffer effect of social support on cognitive frailty for older adults with only childhood or dual adversity. These findings deserve further consideration in the development of public health policies for the prevention of cognitive frailty. This study implies that social support should be considered when preventing cognitive frailty among older adults with dual adversity, which may effectively improve the health and well-being of older adults in rural China.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank the officials of health agencies, all participants and staffs at the study sites for their cooperation.

sec.title: Disclosure statement
sec.p: No potential conflict of interest was reported by the author(s).

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: The datasets used in the current study are not publicly available due to the confidential policy but are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.

sec.title: Supplemental Material
sec.p: Supplemental data for this article can be accessed online at https://doi.org/10.1080/20008066.2025.2543630.
